result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.
result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. NICHOLAS ALLEN BACKMAN

records.addlTxt: No violent contact with V1 in Neenah PD report 22-19947. Defendant does acknowledge they've been advised who the victim(s) is/are. Absolute sobriety. No alcohol consumption or possession. Do not be on the premises of any bars or taverns. Comply with the conditions of the Alcohol 24/7 Program.  The Defendant shall bring the alcohol monitoring device to every hearing. No possession of firearms. No possession of dangerous weapons.

3:17 PM Defendant NICHOLAS ALLEN BACKMAN appeared by video.  Prosecuting attorney Stephanie Ann Stauber Ms. in court for the State of Wisconsin. Given/has complaint. Advised of charges & potential penalties. Advised of rights. The defendant authorized the Court to send text message reminders of upcoming court hearings. The Court did confirm with the State that they are in compliance with Marsy's Law. The Court notes there is no victim present that wishes to make a statement. Record closed @ 330
faxed to Sheriff's Office for handout to DE with their copy of the criminal complaint.
